questions.question: What is a neural network?

options.A: A computer program that simulates human behavior
options.B: A mathematical model inspired by biological neural networks that processes information through interconnected nodes
options.C: A database system for storing large amounts of data
options.D: A programming language for artificial intelligence

questions.question: Which component of a neural network processes and transmits information?

options.B: Database

questions.question: What is backpropagation in neural networks?

options.A: A method to input data into the network
options.B: An algorithm that calculates gradients and updates weights to minimize error
options.C: A way to store network parameters
options.D: A technique to visualize network architecture

questions.question: What is the purpose of the activation function in a neural network?

options.B: To introduce non-linearity and help the network learn complex patterns

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common activation function?

options.B: Sigmoid

questions.question: What is a deep neural network?

options.A: A neural network with many input nodes
options.B: A neural network with multiple hidden layers
options.C: A neural network that processes images only
options.D: A neural network with high accuracy

questions.question: What is the purpose of the loss function in neural networks?

options.A: To measure the difference between predicted and actual outputs
options.B: To activate neurons

questions.question: What is dropout in neural networks?

options.B: A regularization technique that randomly deactivates neurons during training
options.D: A way to structure network layers

questions.question: What is a convolutional neural network (CNN) primarily used for?

options.B: Image recognition and processing

questions.question: What is batch normalization?

options.A: A method to organize training data
options.B: A technique to normalize layer inputs during training
options.C: A way to initialize network weights

questions.question: What is the vanishing gradient problem?

options.A: When the network has too many layers
options.B: When gradients become extremely small, making training difficult
options.C: When the network uses too much memory
options.D: When the input data is too large

questions.question: What is a recurrent neural network (RNN)?

options.B: A network with connections forming a directed cycle
options.C: A network with only one layer
options.D: A network that only uses binary data

questions.question: What is the purpose of learning rate in neural networks?

options.A: To control how much weights are updated during training
options.B: To determine the network size

questions.question: What is transfer learning in neural networks?

options.B: Using a pre-trained model for a new but related task

questions.question: What is the purpose of the softmax function?

options.B: To convert outputs into probability distributions

questions.question: What is an epoch in neural network training?

options.B: One complete pass through the entire training dataset
options.C: A method to save the model

questions.question: What is the purpose of early stopping?

options.B: To prevent overfitting by stopping training when validation error increases

questions.question: What is a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network?

options.B: A special type of RNN designed to handle long-term dependencies
options.C: A network that only processes short sequences
options.D: A network with limited memory capacity

questions.question: What is the purpose of data augmentation in neural networks?

options.B: To artificially increase the training dataset size by creating modified versions of existing data

questions.question: What is the difference between supervised and unsupervised learning in neural networks?

options.A: Supervised learning requires more computing power
options.B: Supervised learning uses labeled data for training, while unsupervised learning finds patterns in unlabeled data
options.C: Unsupervised learning is always more accurate
options.D: There is no difference between them
